Kaoru Takeishi a, Ken-ich Aika b,. a Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Shizuoka University, 5-1, Jouhoku 3-choume, Hamamatsu 432, Japan b Department of Environmental Chemistry and Engineering, Interdisciplinary Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 4259 Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama 226, Japan Received 20 February 1995; revised 28 April 1995; accepted 26 May 1995 Abstract On Raney ruthenium catalysts pretreated with a mixed gas of water vapor and helium, the rate of hydrogenation of CO2 was higher by three orders of magnitude than that of the hydrogenation of CO. However, the former reaction gives methane almost exclusively, while the latter reaction can give methanol. Since supported ruthenium catalysts usually catalyze both hydrogenations of CO and CO2 with almost the same rate, Raney ruthenium catalysts were shown to be uniquely active for hydro- genation of CO2 under the conditions studied here. The weight-based activity of methane production from CO2 and hydrogen is much higher than that of the supported catalysts at 353-413 K and under 80 kPa. Methanol was also produced from CO2 on Raney ruthenium catalysts, though the selectivity was negligibly lower than that from CO. With the mixtures of CO, CO2, and H2 at 353 K and under 80 kPa, CO was preferentially hydrogenated, unless composition of CO was very small. Reaction mechanisms of CO-CO2 hydrogenation are proposed. Keywords: Raney; Ruthenium; Hydrogenation; Methane; Methanol; Carbon dioxide; Carbon monoxide 1. Introduction In hydrogenation of carbon monoxide (CO), ruthenium (Ru) catalysts usually dissociate the C-O bond easily and are effective for methanation [ 1,2 ] and Fischer- Tropsch synthesis [ 3-5 ]. However, Raney Ru catalysts pretreated by a mixed gas of HaO vapor and He produce methanol with high activity and high selectivity * Corresponding author. Tel. ( + 81-45) 9245416, fax. [6,7]. H20-He pretreatment oxidizes aluminum (A1) and Ru atoms probably adjacent to A1 on the surface of the catalysts. Existence of cationic Ru (Ru"+) stabilized with the oxidized AI (A1203) has been discussed as the active center of methanol synthesis keeping the C-O bond, while metallic parts (Ru activating H atoms. In this paper, Raney Ru catalysts were used for the hydrogenation of carbon dioxide (CO2). The activity and the selectivity were studied and compared with the reaction of CO. The nature of the Raney Ru was compared with the supported Ru catalysts which had been well studied. 2. Experimental 2.1. Experimental system A scheme of the apparatus used is shown in Fig. 1. The main part was made of Pyrex glass and connected to an on-line gas chromatograph (GC, Shimadzu GC- 4BPTF) for reactants and products analyses. Hydrogen (99.99%) and helium (99.995%) were purified by passing through a cold trap with dehydrated molecular sieves 5A at 77 K, respectively. CO2 (99.5%) and CO (99.95%) were deoxygen- ated with a 'Gasclean GC-RX' (an oxygen remover produced by Nikka Seiko Co., Ltd.) and passed through an MS-5A trap at 194 K, respectively. The treated CO2 K. Takeishi, K.-i. Aika/Applied Catalysis A: General 133 (1995) 31-45 33 was further purified by fractional distillation. Nitrogen (99.99%) was deoxygen- ated with a 'Gasclean GC-RX' and passed through a liquid-N2 cold trap. 2.2. Development of Raney Ru catalysts Suitable weights (0.6-2.0 g) of Raney Ru alloy (Ru / A1 = 50 / 50 in weight ratio) were leached with about 5 mol dm-3 potassium hydroxide aqueous solution at about 373 K until H2 evolution ceased (about 2 h) [ 6-8 ]. After cooling, they were washed several times with decantation until the pH of the solutions reached 7. A few washings with decantation followed. The leached sample powders were care- fully transferred to the catalyst chambers together with some water under deoxy- genated N2 gas atmosphere, and evacuated for 10 h at room temperature. 2.3. Pretreatment of Raney Ru catalysts The catalyst in the reaction chamber was reduced with a circulating H2 (53 kPa) at 573 K for 1.5 h with a liquid-N2 cold trap, and evacuated for 1 h. The reduction of the catalyst was repeated again for 2 h, and the catalyst was evacuated for 1.5 h. The reduced catalyst was then pretreated with circulating H20 (2.7 kPa)-He (27 kPa) gas mixture at a temperature of 373, 473, or 573 K for 15 h. After the H20- He pretreatment, the mixed gas was circulated with the liquid-N2 cold trap for 1 h to remove of H20, and evacuation for 1.5 h was carried out. Before the reaction, the BET surface area from N2 physisorption was measured at 77 K and the H2 chemisorption was determined under 30 kPa at 273 K. The percent of exposed metallic Ru was estimated by: Total amount of chemisorbed hydrogen atoms (atoms g-l)/BET surface area (m2 g- 1)/Weight of the catalyst (g) / 1.63 1019 (atoms m-z) 100 [9]. 2.4. COe and CO hydrogenation over Raney Ru catalysts CO2 hydrogenation was carried out at 353 K and under an 80-kPa pressure of CO:/H2 ( = 1/3 molar ratio) gas mixture. Products of reaction were condensed by a dry-ice and methanol cold trap, a part of the apparatus. CO hydrogenation was also carried out for comparison under the same conditions using CO/Hz ( 1/3 molar ratio) mixed gas. Methanol, ethanol, and hydrocarbons with a carbon number of 3 to 8, recovered as products, were quantitatively analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) using a flame ionization detector (FID) and two columns filled with Porapak Q (80-100 mesh, 2 m long, diameter= 3 mm) and Porapak R (80-100 mesh, 1 m long, diameter = 3 mm) in series. Gaseous methane and ethane separated by acti- vated charcoal (80-100 mesh, 2 m long, diameter = 3 mm) were detected by FID, and the separated CO2 was detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Alcohol and hydrocarbon selectivities were calculated as the carbon base percentage 34 K. Takeishi, K.-i. Extraction of Run + by thiourea solution After the hydrogenation, amount ofRun + on the Raney Ru surface was measured by a thiourea solution method [ 7 ]. The catalysts after the reactions were transferred into 20-ml mixed solution (81% thiourea aqueous solution 0.18 ml, 12 mol dm-3 HC1 aq. 0.83 ml, and ethanol) in Schlenk's tubes under argon atmosphere. The thiourea solutions were deoxygenated by 10-min Nz gas bubbling before the extrac- tion. The cationic Ru was extracted with the thiourea solution by a 20-min reflux at 363 K, and the solution was filtered under Ar atmosphere. The amount of Run thiourea complexes in the solution was measured by using a spectrophotometer (Hitachi Model 100-40). RuC13-thiourea solutions were used as a calibration stan- dard for the spectrophotometric measurement of the Run thiourea samples at a wavelength of 620 nm. 3. Results 3.1. HeO-He pretreatment effect on COe hydrogenation and CO hydrogenation The results of the reactions carried out for 5 h at 353 K under 80 kPa (C02/ Ha = CO/Ha = 1/3) are shown in Table 1. Two reduced Raney Ru catalysts (0.3 g), and three HzO-He (at 373,473, and 573 K) pretreated catalysts were used for CO2 and CO hydrogenation. The conversion was less than 5%. In previous papers [6,7] Raney catalysts were not reduced by H2 before the H20-He pretreatment. Therefore, their BET surface area and percent of reduced surface Ru were decreased due to the higher treatment temperature. However, in this study Raney catalysts were reduced by Ha at 573 K before HzO-He pretreat- ments. By this procedure, the BET surface area and percent of reduced surface Ru gave almost reproducible values, 33-38 m2 g- ~ and 73-79%, respectively, except the untreated catalysts. HzO-He pretreatment resulted in lower BET surface area, higher surface percent of Ru and higher amount of Run +, irrespective of the pretreatment temperature. Therefore, the differences in each value of the BET surface area and the percent of exposed Ruare neglected as the factors of the catalyst activity in this study. Supported Ru catalysts mainly produce methane from CO2 and Ha [ 10,11]. Raney Ru catalysts studied here also produces methane, yet small amounts of methanol and ethanol were also produced from CO2 hydrogenation. The activity K. Takeishi, K.-i. Suggested mechanism of C0-C02 hydrogenation over Raney Ru These results suggest that CO is preferentially hydrogenated compared with CO2 unless CO content is extremely small. This is responsible for the fact that the product distribution pattern and the reaction rate of hydrogenation of the CO2-CO mixture are almost the same as those of pure CO hydrogenation. It is suggested that CO molecules are adsorbed onto Ru metal surface more strongly than CO2 molecules, and adsorbed CO molecules are activated, dissociated and further hydro- genated on Ru. CO2 cannot be adsorbed under the existence of CO. However, if there are no adsorbed CO molecules, CO2 molecules can be adsorbed on Ru metal K. Takeishi, K.-i. Amount of methane produced by the hydrogenation rapidly decreased with increas- ing CO ratio from 0 to 0.3. When the CO ratio was more than 0.3, total amount of methane produced by the CO-CO2 hydrogenation was the same as a methane amount produced from CO/H2. Their data obtained by the time programmed reduction suggests that ruthenium is inhibited most strongly by the CO adsorption among the platinum groups. 4.2. Effect of H20-He pretreatment to Raney Ru catalysts Yano et al. [6] have reported that H20-He pretreatment oxidizes surface A1 on Raney Ru with higher temperatures. Produced A13 + is considered to be responsible for methanol production activating C-O bond without breaking on such sites as RuA13+ [6]. We were further successful to extract Run+ by thiourea solution and found that the methanol production is also related with Run +, suggestion the active sites' formation such as RuRun (or with AI3 +) [7]. In this study we proved this again for CO hydrogenation. Ruis also necessary to activated H2. In the case of CO2 hydrogenation, the H20-He pretreatment did not improve the selectivity for methanol formation. Instead, the methanol production was slightly decreased and the methane production was slightly increased. This phenomenon is opposite to that in CO hydrogenation. This is probably because that CO2 is not stabilized on RuRun (A13 + ) sites and the concentration of CO (a), which may be an intermediate from CO2 to C(a), may be quite small. 4.3. Comparison of methane synthesis rates in C02 hydrogenation Inui et al. [ 12,13 ] have reported turnover number for methane formation (NM) and space time yield (STYM) on several catalysts at 500 K. Methane production rate from CO2 and H2 at 500 K on our Raney Ru was estimated to be 0.25 mol g- h- 1 assuming the relationship in Fig. 2. Surface metal site of Raney Ru catalyst is calculated as 0.70 mmol g- l, and volume of that is 0.8 ml g- 1. Therefore, NM and STYM of the Raney Ru catalyst at 500 K are extrapolated as 10X 10-2 s-i and 31 10 mol 1-~ h-~, respectively. The calculated values are listed on Table 4 together with data reported. NM of the Raney Ru (0.10 s - ~ ) was found to be in the similar level to that of 3.3%Ru/SiO2 (0.20 s- 1 ). This suggests that the active site structure of Raney Ru for methanation formation is similar to that of supported Ru. Conclusion Raney Ru was found to be a very effective catalyst for methane synthesis from CO2 and H2. Methanol is formed from CO2 and H2 as from CO and H2 over Raney Ru, but the main products are hydrocarbons, especially methane. The rate of meth- ane production was thousands' times as high as that of methanol production. The per gram activity for methane synthesis by CO2 hydrogenation was much higher than that of supported Ru catalysts because of the high concentration of active sites. However, the turnover number was nearly the same as those on the supported Ru. When CO2-CO mixtures are used as the reactant on Raney Ru, CO hydrogenation takes priority over CO2 hydrogenation. CO molecules adsorb strongly on the Ru metal surface and thus inhibit CO2 adsorption. Product distribution of the CO2-CO hydrogenation was similar to that of the CO hydrogenation, which was explained by the same mechanism. On Raney ruthenium catalysts pretreated with a mixed gas of water vapor and helium, the rate of hydrogenation of CO2 was higher by three orders of magnitude than that of the hydrogenation of CO. However, the former reaction gives methane almost exclusively, while the latter reaction can give methanol. Since supported ruthenium catalysts usually catalyze both hydrogenations of CO and CO2 with almost the same rate, Raney ruthenium catalysts were shown to be uniquely active for hydrogenation of CO2 under the conditions studied here. The weight-based activity of methane production from CO2 and hydrogen is much higher than that of the supported catalysts at 353–413 K and under 80 kPa. Methanol was also produced from CO2 on Raney ruthenium catalysts, though the selectivity was negligibly lower than that from CO. With the mixtures of CO, CO2, and H2 at 353 K and under 80 kPa, CO was preferentially hydrogenated, unless composition of CO was very small. Reaction mechanisms of COCO2 hydrogenation are proposed.
